content.question:
A student conducts an experiment to verify that a collision is elastic. The two objects, object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, travel toward each other, as shown in the figure. The mass and the initial speed of both objects are known. Which of the following equations should the student consider using to verify that the collision is elastic, and why?

Equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>: <math alttext="delta p equals F delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Δ</mi><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover><mo>=</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover><mi>Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

Equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>: <math alttext="the sum of p sub 0 equals the sum of p sub f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Σ</mi><msub><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>Σ</mi><msub><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

Equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>: <math alttext="delta K equals K sub f minus K sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>Δ</mi><mi>K</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

choices.label: Equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> only, because the change in momentum of object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be equal to the negative change of momentum for object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> only, because the conservation of momentum must be verified for the system of object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the change in momentum of object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be equal to the negative change of momentum for object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the difference in the kinetic energy of the system before and after the collision should be determined.

Equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the conservation of momentum must be verified for the system of object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the difference in the kinetic energy of the system before and after the collision should be determined.

content.answer: Equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and equation <math alttext="Roman numeral 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the conservation of momentum must be verified for the system of object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the difference in the kinetic energy of the system before and after the collision should be determined.
